definitions.definition: a structure made of wood or wire supported with posts that is put between two areas of land as a boundary, or around a garden, field, etc. to keep animals in, or to keep people and animals out

examples.text: The two women chatted over the garden fence.
Security guards with dogs patrolled the **perimeter fence**.
The footpath was blocked by a **barbed wire fence**.
The house was surrounded by a white **picket fence**.
She walked over to the tall wooden privacy fence.
There was a cottage garden at the front and a white picket fence.
the fence line separating the United States from Mexico

definitions.definition: a structure that horses must jump over in a race or a competition
a criminal who buys and sells stolen goods
said about people who never seem happy with what they have and always think they could be happier in a different place or situation
to find a solution when you disagree with somebody

examples.text: The White House already is struggling to mend fences with Europe.
Is it too late to mend fences with your ex-wife?

definitions.definition: used to refer to either of two opposite opinions on an issue

examples.text: The two countries are often on opposite sides of the fence when it comes to climate change.
There are arguments on both sides of the aisle.
On the other side of the fence there is anger at the reforms.
It is a proposal approved by people on both sides of the political fence.

definitions.definition: to avoid becoming involved in deciding or influencing something

examples.text: He tends to sit on the fence at meetings.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘defending, defence’): shortening of defence. Compare with fend.
